Explanations about Options.-a(M):
Show both listening and non-listening sockets. With the --interfaces option, show
 interfaces that are not up
Explanations about Options.-c(M): This will cause netstat to print the selected information every second continuously.
Explanations about Options.-l(M): Show only listening sockets. (These are omitted by default.)
Explanations about Options.-n(M): Show numerical addresses instead of trying to determine symbolic host, port or user names.
Explanations about Options.-p(M): Show the PID and name of the program to which each socket belongs.

Explanations about Options.-l(M):
Listen for an incoming connection rather than initiating a connection to a remote
 host. The destination and port to listen on can be specified either as non-optional
 arguments, or with options -s and -p respectively. Cannot be used together with -x
 or -z. Additionally, any timeouts specified with the -w option are ignored.
Explanations about Options.-z(M):
Only scan for listening daemons, without sending any data to them. Cannot be used
 together with -l.

Explanations about Options.-a(M):
Display both listening and non-listening (for TCP this means established
 connections) sockets.
Explanations about Options.-l(M): Display only listening sockets (these are omitted by default).
Explanations about Options.-n(M):
Do not try to resolve service names. Show exact bandwidth values, instead of human-
 readable.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Show all TCP sockets connected to the local HTTPS port (443)
Top-3 Scripts:
so_59993231: #!/bin/bash

for i in {0..255}
do
  echo "$i"
  ss -ant "( src 192.168.1.$i or dst 192.168.1.$i ) and ( ( dport = :80 or dport = :443 ) or ( sport = :443 or sport = :80 ) )"
done

Explanations about Options.-A(C): It lets me scan a network by just running "nmap -A <IP of router or website>" where you then wait up to like 30 seconds and you get an output like  .  "$ nmap -A askubuntu.com". The -P0 is to make sure you get to the machine even if ping is filtered, and -A will show you (among other things) the service and version running at each port.
Explanations about Options.-O(M):
Enables OS detection, as discussed above. Alternatively, you can use -A to enable OS
 detection along with other things.
Explanations about Options.-sV(C): The -sV option makes checks on open ports to determine the actual service running on the port.
Explanations about Options.-sV(M):
Enables version detection, as discussed above. Alternatively, you can use -A, which
 enables version detection among other things.
